channel.title: Laptop Decision Finalization
channel.description:
Alright, awhile ago I created a topic about looking into a laptop. I've dropped the idea for a few months and now I'm really considering the purchase.
[b]Budget: $1,500[/b]
What I'm using this laptop for:
[ul][li]General work (programming, schoolwork, etc.)[/li] [li]General music (iTunes, editing/recording band music, ...)[/li] [li]Low-Medium Gaming. I'm not talking about running games like Battlefield 3 or Skyrim on max settings. I will buy these games for XBox. I am talking about running games like RuneScape in HD, WoW, Dawn of War II, etc. smoothly and without the hassle of problems.[/li][/ul]
I've found this: [url=http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16834230141]http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16834230141[/url] There is also a version with 4GB more RAM for an extra $150. Is the Nvidia Geforce GTX 560M GDDR5 a good graphics card for what I'm going to be using it for?
I know that self-building is a better and cheaper option than buying a pre-built, but I have close to no clue about building one. I just want to purchase a pre-built that is going to allow casual gaming and last me through college. I know these laptops are always improving and you can always upgrade up, but just looking to have a portable computer that will allow me to run my typical desktop tasks.
If you have any recommendations within my budget that will outmatch this Asus, let me know. I don't need to be right on the dot of $1500. I don't need an insane computer, just one that will run games like the ones I listed above.
[b]Questions to answer:[/b]
1) Is 8GB RAM, a 500GB HDD, and the Nvidia Geforce GTX 560M GDDR5 enough? 2) Does your connection speed widely impact your gaming (My download speed is about 250 kb/sec, does this ruin online play or anything?) 3) RECOMMEND ME SOME GAMES :D
I appreciate any help.

item.title: Laptop Decision Finalization
item.dc:creator: @classic mopmans little slave
item.description:
@classic wrote:

t4:

lenovo or asus, no other option.

when did you become so smart? just bought a 500 dollar lenovo i7 2nd gen processor 8gb ram ddr3 and a 700gb hd

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop Decision Finalization
item.dc:creator: @chassy13 Chassy13
item.description:
@chassy13 wrote:

Going with the Clevo one from Malibal. Might wait around for the P170EM version though, comes with Ivy Bridge and a backlit keyboard. If it costs a lot more, just going with the P170HM. I can run BF3 on High with it and that’s about the max graphics game I’ll be playing on it.

Read full topic

[/quote]

item.title: Laptop Decision Finalization
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Mine tends to be fine in the dark, though it’s rarely pitch black in my room cause it ruins my eyes in a matter of minutes. Depends on brightness of the screen I suppose, I wouldn’t worry about it though

edit: ah shit take back what I said earlier, on the top of the page it says it has a GTX485M GPU, which is well… awesome, but on the options below it only has the GTX560M selected, which is the same as the Asus… In that case the Asus is probably better for the buck.

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop Decision Finalization
item.dc:creator: @chassy13 Chassy13
item.description:
@chassy13 wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:26, topic:434384”][quote author=Chassy13 link=topic=537105.msg3929256#msg3929256 date=1330530666]
I’m stuck between the Asus and the Satori. Any recommendations? I can afford either one so any final opinions can really help.

Asus

Satori

Both seem to be decent machines.
[/quote]
The satori has a pretty superior graphics card, less RAM though, but who needs 16gb?
However it does need an operating system, but with the money you save you could easily buy W7.

I’d say the Satori, even though I’ve never heard of them.[/quote]

Satori = Sager = Clevo

Apparently they build pretty tough computers. From everywhere I’m looking the Asus tends to end up in keyboard problems or display errors.

Generally, can you see a keyboard in the dark if the laptop is running something? The Satori lacks a backlit keyboard, and just want to confirm that it doesn’t make a large difference.

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop Decision Finalization
item.dc:creator: @chassy13 Chassy13
item.description:
@chassy13 wrote:

What about a Toshiba Qosmio?:
http://www.amazon.com/Toshiba-Qosmio-X775-Q7272-17-3-Inch-Horizon/dp/B0053Y41GM/ref=sr_1_7?ie=UTF8&qid=1330362296&sr=8-7

I want to go with the Asus, but I’m worried (probably overworried) about the touchpad issue. A guy said he did a driver update on one of the reviews and it fixed his problem with the keyboard/touchpad. Is Asus customer support decently reliable? If I’m spending this chunk of money I need this computer to last me a few years.

Why is this one cheaper than the other Asus? Is it just because it’s newegg or what?:
http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=34-230-142&SortField=0&SummaryType=0&Pagesize=10&PurchaseMark=&SelectedRating=1&VideoOnlyMark=False&VendorMark=&IsFeedbackTab=true&Keywords=%28keywords%29&Page=1

item.title: Laptop Decision Finalization
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Chassy13, post:10, topic:434384”]Thinking about purchasing the one Coon has. Will the NVidia GTX 460M be enough to run what I wanted?

Bringing back the download speed issue - It’ll just take forever to download games from Steam right?[/quote]
downloading makes use of the hard drive, network card, and internet connection. most hard drives write at a minimal speed of 20-30MB/s, so unless you can download that fast the network is your bottleneck.

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop Decision Finalization
item.dc:creator: @MistaBigBoss MistaBigBoss
item.description:
@MistaBigBoss wrote:

If you’re going to buy a laptop, choose Asus, like I did, great price (€750) and great performance (i7 quad core 2nd gen, 6GB RAM, 17.3" screen, GT 540M, multi touch trackpad, half the laptop is in aluminium, 750 GB HDD,…)

Imagine that I’m able to play Crysis 2 with high settings in 1280 x 720 at 60 fps with a GT 540M 1GB DDR3, with a GTX 560M GDDR5, you will be able to do the same at a much higher resolution. Any chip that has GTX in its name is meant for gaming. GTX cards/chips are the most powerful that come in the Geforce series.

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop Decision Finalization
item.dc:creator: @chassy13 Chassy13
item.description:
@chassy13 wrote:

I’m going to keep looking around, the reviews for the Asus ones I’ve been looking at make me nervous. Constant track pad failure issues amongst other things, although I did find a helpful post about it. I’d end up buying an external mouse anyway but this will remain on my list for now.

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop Decision Finalization
item.dc:creator: @Spades Spades
item.description:
@Spades wrote:

I say that laptop will do what you expect it to do, decent Graphics Card, Good RAM, the HDD could be bigger, but I’m sure you have external storage. For Gaming That will do, for coding/school work, that will be no problem, you would have no problem multi-tasking. Your Internet speed is a tad better then mine, but it isn’t very good for gaming, novice gaming, or just not realling caring, just playing the game for fun your internet would be more then fine, but if you were to do hard-core gaming, you would want to look at 10MB+ internet for flawless gaming and no lag.

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop Decision Finalization
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

The G74SX is just the 2012 model of the G series in Asus laptops. The G73JW is the 2011 model. If you don’t mind dropping the bit of extra though it would be more worth it to get the G74SX, although it looks like they just upgraded the graphics card, slapped in a bit more ram and a larger HDD. Currently doing some digging on getting the 560M into the G73JW.

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop Decision Finalization
item.dc:creator: @chassy13 Chassy13
item.description:
@chassy13 wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:13, topic:434384”][quote author=Chassy13 link=topic=537105.msg3927010#msg3927010 date=1330313873]
Thinking about purchasing the one Coon has. Will the NVidia GTX 460M be enough to run what I wanted?

Bringing back the download speed issue - It’ll just take forever to download games from Steam right?
[/quote]
I run Minecraft at 120+ FPS on adverage.
Skyrim (no real FPS number) but I ran it on medium and NEVER saw FPS lag, so it surely stayed 40+. I did try it on high, don’t remember playing long though. The only tip is to keep it out of a very dusty environment. The fans will need cleaning if you don’t. Although I bought a $20 cooling fan for it. I’ll look it up and see if you can upgrade the GFX card, but I wouldn’t see why not.

EDIT: A confusing part if you were to purchase the g73jw, the CPU is generally underclocked at 1.7GHz, but will powerboost itself up to 3.2GHz when needed.[/quote]

It looks like this is a version with a 560M gfx card (and increased RAM), but the reviews make it seem kind of sketchy:
http://www.amazon.com/ASUS-G74SX-DH71-17-3-Inch-Gaming-Laptop/dp/B005PAJI4Y/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1330322877&sr=8-2 The next step up from that is the $1800 one.

As long as the 460M and the laptop in general will run the games I want smoothly, it doesn’t matter to me. I’m not playing games like Skyrim, I’m playing simpler. I don’t have any specifics in mind, but things like LoL, Dawn of War II, maybe a little better than that but none of those, "YOU NEED A HUGE RIG TO RUN THESE GRAPHICS (BF3, SKYRIM, etc.).

Read full topic

@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“Chassy13, post:10, topic:434384”]Thinking about purchasing the one Coon has. Will the NVidia GTX 460M be enough to run what I wanted?

Bringing back the download speed issue - It’ll just take forever to download games from Steam right?[/quote]
I run Minecraft at 120+ FPS on adverage.
Skyrim (no real FPS number) but I ran it on medium and NEVER saw FPS lag, so it surely stayed 40+. I did try it on high, don’t remember playing long though. The only tip is to keep it out of a very dusty environment. The fans will need cleaning if you don’t. Although I bought a $20 cooling fan for it. I’ll look it up and see if you can upgrade the GFX card, but I wouldn’t see why not.

EDIT: A confusing part if you were to purchase the g73jw, the CPU is generally underclocked at 1.7GHz, but will powerboost itself up to 3.2GHz when needed.

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop Decision Finalization
item.dc:creator: @chassy13 Chassy13
item.description:
@chassy13 wrote:

[quote=“RandQm, post:6, topic:434384”][quote author=Chassy13 link=topic=537105.msg3926895#msg3926895 date=1330307907]
) Is 8GB RAM, a 500GB HDD, and the Nvidia Geforce GTX 560M GDDR5 enough?
[/quote]

WHAT 1500?
My laptop has 12gb RAM, 1TG HDD and same ^
was 999€ like a half year ago so prob close to 900 now.
Where the hell do you shop[/quote]

Those are the specs inside the pre-built laptop I listed. I’ve seen an MSI laptop with the specs you have for about the same price of the one I listed, but the reviews made me turn away.

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:5, topic:434384”]Ram does have an effect. How does nobody understand this. Slow ram chips do exist. Especially with only having 1GB of RAM there is hardly enough to run minecraft and an OS. Minecraft alone tries to reserve 1GB at startup. I don’t know enough to to critique what your looking at.

EDIT: I personally use this laptop. The only time it lagged was when I temporarily had to put a 32bit OS onto it so I could fix it after personal mistakes. Although it is a year old now. Although dropping it is an issue, the screen breaks easy on about a 3+ft fall lol. Expected with any laptop though.
http://www.amazon.com/G73JW-A1-Republic-Gamers-17-3-Inch-Gaming/dp/B0041RRS0I[/quote]

Yeah I’ve looked at the A1 and A2 but they’re getting out of my budget. If you’d expect it to last for multiple years (at least 4), then it would be an option I guess. Not the A2 though, that’s like $1,800.

Read full topic
